Business Value: Continuously validates network devices against company configuration standards, preventing security gaps and policy violations

Rapidly deploys standardized configurations across thousands of devices. 
Achievement: Deployed 30,000 TACACS configs across 7,000+ devices in 35 minutes

Automatically modifies device configurations based on discovered network context and peer information 
(e.g., tagging wireless controller uplinks with '#wireless', updating QoS policies based on device type)
Monitors interface errors, CRC, duplex mismatches, and speed degradation to detect performance issues before they impact users
Executes ping tests across all network links on target devices to validate end-to-end connectivity and identify silent failures
Identifies unstable network links with excessive flap counts, enabling proactive replacement before outages occur
Flags devices with extremely high uptimes that may be running outdated code or harboring memory leaks requiring maintenance windows
Identifies devices running resource-intensive debug commands and automatically disables them to prevent performance degradation
Discovers devices with uncommitted configuration changes and either saves or alerts, preventing configuration loss during unexpected reboots
Discovers fiber optic media mismatches between link endpoints (e.g., SX vs LX) that cause intermittent connectivity issues
Detects OSPF interface type mismatches (broadcast vs point-to-point) that prevent neighbor relationships from forming
Identifies ports accidentally wired back to the same device, typically from cabling errors during installation
Detects port-channels operating with only one active member, eliminating the redundancy they were designed to provide
Identifies network devices lacking redundant uplinks, highlighting single points of failure in the infrastructure
Finds wireless access points connected to only one controller, creating availability risks during controller maintenance

Tracks wireless client counts over time across all APs to optimize capacity and detect overloaded cells, 
surpassing Cisco DNA’s single-AP client visibility with network-wide historical insights.
Parses global routing and BGP tables to validate route propagation, detect suboptimal paths, and identify routing anomalies
Performs advanced traceroute from Linux or Cisco devices, enriched with IP database and DNS lookups for better path visualization
Uses multi-protocol testing suite to determine actual device status, even when behind firewalls or with ICMP blocked
Automatically collects show commands from local and remote devices, then leverages AI with RAG for intelligent root cause analysis
Decrypts device local credentials through hash processing or automated login scripts for emergency access recovery
